name: solidago-canadensis
wildlife-value: This plant supports Wavy-lined Emerald (Synchlora aerata) larvae. The pollen and nectar are attractive to many pollinators including monarch butterflies. The flowers and leaves are eaten by deer and birds will eat the seeds.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: This brown seed is oblong-shaped with white hair attached to the tip to allow dispersal by the wind.
flower-description: Branching clusters of yellow flower heads at the top of the plant. Pyramidal clusters of flowers are broadly spreading and cascading, with 100 to 1300+ flowers in the cluster. Flowers are about 1/8 inch across with usually 8 to 15 petals (ray flowers) surrounding a central disc with usually 3 to 6 disc flowers.  Commercially, can be used as a filler flower in floral arrangements.  In the garden, it blooms in late summer to fall when other summer flowers are done blooming. Blooms from August to October.
leaf-description: 4-6 inches long and 1 inch wide green leaves are lanceolate to broadly linear, alternate leaves and tapered with spaced sharp teeth. The surface is smooth with possible hairs on veins underneath.
stem-description: Green to reddish straight stems with hairs up to 6 feet tall
uses: It has been used in folk medicine and has anti-inflammatory properties. It has been used to treat wounds, allergies, TB, arthritis, asthma, hypertension and as a diuretic.
